newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Woodside awards NW Shelf contract.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Woodside awards NW Shelf contract.

text.p: Woodside Petroleum Ltd announced on Monday it had awarded a design and management contract for a second trunkline for its North West Shelf offshore gas production facilities to a joint venture between Brown & Root Engineering Pty Ltd and JP Kenny Pty Ltd.
The initial contract commitment was for preliminary engineering which is expected to be completed by mid-1997 at an estimated cost of $3 million, Woodside said in a statement.

"Subject to construction of a second trunkline receiving a formal go-ahead, the Kenny/Brown & Root joint venture will proceed to detailed design and provide project management services for the remainder of the project," it said.
In October, the North West Shelf partners unveiled a A$6.0 billion expansion of the project.

Woodside said the existing subsea trunkline from the North West Shelf project's offshore facilities to the onshore gas treatment plant was approaching its capacity limits with existing sales commitments.
"A second trunkline will be required to transport additional domestic gas volumes to shore, in the short term and to cater for expansion of LNG (Liquefied Natural Gas) production," it said.
The North West Shelf joint venturers were expected to commit to the second offshore trunkline once sufficient new market opportunities were confirmed, Woodside said.
The company said contracts for major components of the trunkline development project were expected to be awarded from mid-1997, depending on the eventual development schedule.
Current planning is based on a possible commissioning date of 2000, Woodside said.
The equal stakeholders in the North West Shelf gas project are Woodside, The Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd British Petroleum Plc, Chevron Corp Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Japan Australia LNG (MIMI) Pty Ltd.
